title: Ticket #1790: Allow for policy adjustment via qedit/chirp for running jobs
description: Using condor_qedit to edit a job updates the classad within the schedd, but it doesn't send that update through to the startd running the job. This makes is impossible to update job policy for a running job.
remarks:
2010-Dec-03 12:36:47 by matt:
Ticket #1598: using qedit to update periodic* exprs on running jobs. 

    It would be advantageous to be able to update the periodic* expressions using qedit, currently it is not allowed. A couple ideas have been passed around, one possible solution is to allow for an explicit push schedd->shadows of elements which have +UpdateExprs in their submission file.

2010-Dec-20 11:49:06 by jfrey:
Here are my comments on the proposed patch:

  • I'd rather avoid adding the JobDirty attribute to the job ad. It's not useful to the user and the daemons don't need it to be stored persistently on disk. Instead of having the gridmanager query for jobs with JobDirty==true, how about having a GetAllDirtyAttributesByConstraint() call, similar to GetAllJobsByConstraint(), that iterates over the DirtyJobIDs list? That would be much more efficient and not require a new job attribute.

  • DCSchedd::clearDirtyAttrs() should take a list of job ids. Otherwise, the gridmanager can end up making a lot of separate connections to the schedd needlessly. Better yet, roll it into DCSChedd::actOnJobs() as a new type of action.

  • In the CLEAR_DIRTY_JOB_ATTRS command protocol, there's no acknowledgement sent to the client. This isn't a problem if you roll this command into actOnJobs().

  • In SetAttribute(), notification of the shadow/gridmanager is triggered only if SETDIRTY is set and the job is RUNNING. The gridmanager also handles idle jobs, and should be notified for those jobs as well.

  • In GetDirtyAttributes(), you end up unparsing and reparsing each ExprTree when you add it to the udpate ad. It would be a little more efficient to make a deep copy of the tree and insert that into the new ad.

  • In the send/receive stubs for GetDirtyAttributes(), you unparse the ClassAd and send it as a single string. Why not use ClassAd::put() and ClassAd::initFromStream(), as the other stubs do?

  • qedit.cpp always uses the new CONDOR_SetAttributeByConstraint2 queue-management command. Thus, it can't talk to older schedds. Some kind of backwards-compatibility check should be there. That can be as simple as retrying without SETDIRTY if the first attempt fails.

  • The commented-out code in schedd.cpp should be removed.
